charts_meta.name: All Missing from CMDB by OS
Options for Resolving CMDB Completeness and Accuracy Issues
CMDB Record Status & Missing from CMDB by OS

config.text:
Overview


This dashboard helps ensure data quality in your CMDB by providing insights into devices and fields missing from ServiceNow. It is designed to help identify assets not found in the ServiceNow and highlight discrepancies such as missing data fields.

Completeness

A common requirement for most ServiceNow deployments is to ensure that the asset data in ServiceNow is complete. To meet this requirement, multiple sources of asset information are used to populate any missing assets. Using Axonius, we can connect to all sources of asset information to help ensure that the asset data in ServiceNow is complete by comparing the existing records in your environment against those in ServiceNow.


In most environments, some assets may be reported as missing from ServiceNow; however, after further investigation, it is determined that these assets are not required in ServiceNow because they are logical asset records for DNS or non-corporate assets. If this occurs, tagging in Axonius can be used to identify these false positives as exceptions for reporting.

Accuracy

Another common requirement for most ServiceNow deployments is to ensure that the asset data in ServiceNow is accurate and up-to-date. CMDB information is typically a snapshot in time and usually involves some level of manual effort to create, update, or decommission the CMDB records. Axonius can utilize the asset data we have gathered from all your asset sources to ensure that the asset data in ServiceNow is up-to-date.


Below is a list of common items that require validation and updates in ServiceNow.

- Host name

- IPs

- MACs

- Serial number

- OS Distribution

displayDescription.text: The device's operating system type (eg: Windows, OS X, Linux).

config.text:
Completeness

The creation of assets in ServiceNow can be manual, automated with integrations, or a mixture of both. Assets or fields on the asset may be missing when creating assets, resulting in incomplete information in ServiceNow.


Using the information from the adapters that are configured in Axonius, incomplete information can be surfaced, reported, and resolved.

config.text:
Missing Fields

When creating asset records in ServiceNow, the asset records may contain missing data because the information is not yet known. Once the information is known, the fields should be updated; however, this process may not exist or may be completely manual. Even automated updates may lack context for a device due to a lack of integrations with specific tools.


Using the adapters that Axonius provides to connect to all data sources enables Axonius to have a broader view of assets, which can be used to resolve any missing fields in ServiceNow.


The ServiceNow Missing Fields chart provides a summary of all fields missing from ServiceNow for which Axonius has information. This information can be shared with the ServiceNow team and used to close any missing fields in ServiceNow asset records.

config.text:
Incorrect Values

After a record has been created in ServiceNow, changes may occur on the asset that do not get updated in the ServiceNow asset record. In some cases, this may be caused by differences in format between specific tools and ServiceNow, typos, or other issues. Any discrepancies should be investigated to determine the cause of the issue.


During the investigation, if it is found that the issue is a formatting issue, modifications can be made in the Axonius query logic to resolve the issue. Any other issues caused by changes or typos should be resolved to ensure that ServiceNow has the accurate and up-to-date information on the asset.


The Incorrect Host Name logic requires the 'Remove domain from preferred hostname' setting to be enabled in the system settings, as recommended in the Axonius Article 'What System Configurations are Recommended by Axonius?'

config.text:
CMDB Adapter Counts

CMDBs typically contain information about assets in the environment that may not be available in any other data source. Reviewing these assets may provide information on additional adapters that need to be deployed, decommissioned records that need to be removed, or stale records.


If unnecessary assets are found, the ServiceNow adapter provides the ability to filter the assets fetched and prevent the retrieval of assets with specific statuses, fields, and other criteria. Common uses for these filters include removing decommissioned assets and specific asset types from being fetched.

690b61f1dc9940a5696d0c1c.name: Options for Resolving CMDB Completeness and Accuracy Issues

config.text:
Options for Resolving CMDB Completeness and Accuracy Issues

Multiple options exist to assist in resolving issues related to CMDB completeness and accuracy, but specific options may be more suitable in certain situations.

Manual

In some cases, it may be faster to use a manual option to share information from Axonius to the ServiceNow team.


Exporting a CSV and emailing the information to the ServiceNow team is an effective way to share information quickly. If this information needs to be shared regularly, consider creating a Report or an Action to generate the CSV and send the results to the correct team, or create a ticket in ServiceNow with the necessary information. By using any of these options, Axonius can be configured with the relevant settings, and the information can be manually triggered.


Alternatively, access to Axonius could be provided to the ServiceNow team, which would enable the team to review and make decisions on how to resolve any issues directly within Axonius. In some cases, this can result in the ServiceNow team using the Axonius Actions Center to manually trigger the creation or updating of records in ServiceNow.

Automated CMDB Reconciliation

In most cases, automated CMDB Reconciliation is the desired state to ensure that ServiceNow is complete and accurate. To accomplish this, the Action Center offers multiple actions for creating and updating asset records, which can be triggered as Enforcement actions or Workflows. Each of these actions enables specific configurations to ensure that the necessary information to create or update a record is sent to ServiceNow, allowing for customizations needed to meet specific requirements.


Testing and validation of the expected workflow is expected. In some cases, different actions are required for each asset type (e.g., Windows, Linux, Cloud, VM) to ensure that the correct information is sent to ServiceNow.

Out of Scope Assets

Add the tag "ServiceNow CMDB Exception:" to each asset that meets the criteria for out-of-scope assets. This tagging option enables the tracking of reasons for exceptions by appending the reason to the end of the tag.


Example Exceptions

- ServiceNow CMDB Exception: Personal Asset

- ServiceNow CMDB Exception: Vendor Asset

- ServiceNow CMDB Exception: Logical DNS Record

- ServiceNow CMDB Exception: Cluster Object


This should be automated using a saved query and an Enforcement Center action that defines assets considered out of scope.

Accuracy

ServiceNow, like most CMDBs, requires some manual effort to create, update, or decommission asset records. This manual effort can lead to accuracy issues with asset information if the information is missing or incorrect.


Axonius can identify data accuracy issues for reporting and resolution by using the information from the configured adapters.

additional_filter.filter: ({{QueryID=66eaf2878dbe629a9fa1b4ff}}) and not (("adapters_data.service_now_adapter.id" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) and not ("labels" == regex("ServiceNow CMDB Exception:", "i")) and (("specific_data.data.hostname_preferred" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) and (("specific_data.data.network_interfaces.ips" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":[]}))) and (("specific_data.data.network_interfaces.mac" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) and (("specific_data.data.os.distribution_preferred" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) and ((("specific_data.data.device_serial" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) or (("specific_data.data.cloud_id" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))))

config.text:
Missing from CMDB - Required Fields

Most ServiceNow deployments have specific fields that have been identified as required before an asset record can be created. These required fields may change depending on whether the asset is physical hardware, cloud-deployed, or deployed using on-prem virtualization.


This chart helps identify the number of assets that could be created in ServiceNow to complete the completeness use case by providing reporting on the number of assets that have the required fields versus those that are missing one or more fields.


- Host name

- IPs

- MACs

- Serial number OR Cloud ID

- OS Distribution

690b61f1dc9940a5696d0c25.name: CMDB Record Status & Missing from CMDB by OS

config.text:
CMDB Record Status & Missing from CMDB by OS

Depending on the asset details, a specific asset may or may not need to exist in ServiceNow. It is recommended to review the assets missing from ServiceNow to determine if they are exceptions or if a record needs to be created for the asset.


Common reasons to exclude an asset from the CMDB may include that the asset type or OS type is out of scope, the asset is personal, or it belongs to a vendor or partner.


During this review, tags can be used to identify any false positives and review the assets that were found to be missing from ServiceNow. Information on how to tag assets is included in the Exceptions Management section at the bottom of this dashboard.

Important Note


This dashboard space utilizes saved filters to change the charts to show information across the following asset types.

- All Servers

- All Windows Servers

- All Linux Servers

- All Workstations

- All Windows Workstations

- All macOS Workstations


Please use the saved filters in the upper right corner of the dashboard to switch between the asset types.

query.filter: ((("specific_data.data.os.is_windows_server_preferred" == true) or (("specific_data.data.os.type_preferred" in ["FreeBSD","Linux"]) and (("specific_data.data.os.distribution_preferred" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) and not ("specific_data.data.os.distribution_preferred" == "Junos OS")) or (("specific_data.data.os.type_preferred" in ["Data ONTAP","IBM","NetApp ONTAP","Oracle","Solaris","VMWare"]) or ("specific_data.data.os.os_str" == regex("^(?!windows).*(?:emc|storage).*$", "i")) or ("specific_data.data.device_model_preferred" == regex("^(?:UCS[A-Z]|N[0-9]{2}-[A-Z][0-9]{4}).*$", "i"))) or ("labels" in ["LSA","WSA"]))) and not ("labels" in ["EXLSA","EXLWA","EXWSA"])
query.onlyExpressionsFilter: ((("specific_data.data.os.is_windows_server_preferred" == true) or (("specific_data.data.os.type_preferred" in ["FreeBSD","Linux"]) and (("specific_data.data.os.distribution_preferred" == ({"$exists":true,"$ne":""}))) and not ("specific_data.data.os.distribution_preferred" == "Junos OS")) or (("specific_data.data.os.type_preferred" in ["Data ONTAP","IBM","NetApp ONTAP","Oracle","Solaris","VMWare"]) or ("specific_data.data.os.os_str" == regex("^(?!windows).*(?:emc|storage).*$", "i")) or ("specific_data.data.device_model_preferred" == regex("^(?:UCS[A-Z]|N[0-9]{2}-[A-Z][0-9]{4}).*$", "i"))) or ("labels" in ["LSA","WSA"]))) and not ("labels" in ["EXLSA","EXLWA","EXWSA"])
